title: Cricket Vocabulary
description: How well do you know the terms of this beloved bat-and-ball sport?

questions.question: In cricket, what is a 'googly'?
options: A wide delivery
A bouncer aimed at the batsman's head
A leg-spin ball that turns the opposite way to expected
A catch taken at slip
questions.explanation: A googly is a deceptive delivery bowled by a leg-spin bowler that turns in the opposite direction, from off to leg for a right-handed batsman.

questions.question: What does 'LBW' stand for in cricket?
options: Last Ball Won
Long Boundary Wide
Left Bat Wing
Leg Before Wicket
questions.explanation: LBW stands for Leg Before Wicket, a way of dismissing a batsman whose leg blocks a ball that would have hit the stumps.

questions.question: In cricket, what is a 'duck'?
options: A type of defensive shot
A method of dodging a bouncer
A score of zero by a batsman
A fielding position near the boundary
questions.explanation: A 'duck' refers to a batsman being dismissed without scoring any runs. A 'golden duck' means out on the first ball faced.

questions.question: What is a 'yorker' in cricket?
options: A catch taken by the bowler off their own bowling
A delivery that pitches at or near the batsman's feet
A spin delivery with extra bounce
A shot played over the wicketkeeper's head
questions.explanation: A yorker is a delivery that lands right at or just inside the batsman's crease near their feet, making it very difficult to play.

questions.question: In cricket, what does 'silly point' refer to?
options: A very close fielding position near the batsman on the off side
An extra delivery in an over
A meaningless run scored off a no-ball
A poor shot selection
questions.explanation: Silly point is a close fielding position on the off side, very near the batsman. It is called 'silly' because of the danger to the fielder.

questions.question: What is a 'maiden over' in cricket?
options: An over bowled by a debutant
An over in which no runs are scored off the bat
The first over of a match
An over with all six deliveries being wides
questions.explanation: A maiden over is one in which no runs are scored off the bat by the batsman. It is a mark of tight bowling.

questions.question: In cricket, what is a 'nightwatchman'?
options: The umpire who oversees evening sessions
The security guard at the ground
A fielder positioned deep on the boundary at night
A lower-order batsman sent in near close of play to protect a better batsman
questions.explanation: A nightwatchman is a lower-order batsman promoted up the order to bat near the end of a day's play to protect a more skilled batsman from getting out.

questions.question: What does 'bowling a hat-trick' mean in cricket?
options: Bowling three no-balls in a row
Bowling an entire over of bouncers
Taking three wickets with three consecutive deliveries
Winning three matches in a row as a bowler
questions.explanation: A hat-trick in cricket is when a bowler takes a wicket on each of three consecutive deliveries, one of the rarest achievements in the sport.

questions.question: In cricket, what is a 'doosra'?
options: A fielding position behind the wicketkeeper
A tied test match
A type of batting grip
A delivery by an off-spinner that turns the other way
questions.explanation: The doosra is a delivery bowled by an off-spin bowler that spins in the opposite direction to the off-break, deceiving the batsman. The word means 'the other one' in Hindi/Urdu.

questions.question: What is the 'crease' in cricket?
options: The edge of the boundary rope
A wrinkle in the pitch surface
The marked lines at each end of the pitch
The seam on the cricket ball
questions.explanation: The crease refers to the set of lines marked at each end of the pitch, including the batting crease (popping crease), bowling crease, and return creases.

questions.question: In cricket, what is a 'century'?
options: 100 consecutive dot balls
A score of 100 runs by an individual batsman
Playing for 100 minutes without a break
A match lasting 100 overs
questions.explanation: A century is when a batsman scores 100 or more runs in a single innings, considered a significant milestone in cricket.

questions.question: What is a 'chinaman' delivery in cricket?
options: A spin ball bowled underarm
A delivery that bounces twice
A fast delivery aimed at the chin
A left-arm wrist spinner's stock ball that turns from off to leg
questions.explanation: A chinaman is the stock delivery of a left-arm wrist spinner (or unorthodox spinner), turning from off to leg for a right-handed batsman.

questions.question: In cricket, what does 'declaration' mean?
options: An appeal to the umpire
A captain voluntarily ending their team's innings
The official start of a match
Announcing the team lineup
questions.explanation: A declaration is when the batting captain voluntarily ends their team's innings before all batsmen are out, usually as a tactical move to give time to bowl out the opposition.

questions.question: What is 'sledging' in cricket?
options: Sliding to stop the ball in the field
Dragging the pitch roller across the ground
Celebrating a wicket excessively
Verbal intimidation of the batsman by fielders
questions.explanation: Sledging is the practice of players making provocative or personal comments to distract or unsettle an opponent, a controversial but common part of the game.

questions.question: In cricket, what is a 'bouncer'?
options: A rejected appeal
A ball that bounces off the pitch and over the boundary
The person who controls crowd access
A short-pitched fast delivery aimed to rise toward the batsman's upper body or head
questions.explanation: A bouncer is a short-pitched delivery from a fast bowler that rises steeply toward the batsman's chest, shoulders, or head, used as an intimidation tactic.
